LIZ CAO: So I'll start
out by introducing myself. So my name is Liz, I'm a
senior program manager at CGOE,

Center for Global
and Online Education. I manage the product management
portfolio for Stanford Online.

So excited to talk
to you all today about what we have in the
professional education

and for product
management offerings. PAX HEHMEYER: And my
name is Pax Hehmeyer,

I'm the director of
academic programs here at CGOE and
Stanford Online. If you heard Liz
hesitate, that's

because our name
has just changed. So if you have been with us
before and you heard SCPD, we are now CGOE, the Stanford
Engineering Center for Global

and Online Education. And I'm going to
provide more detail about the credit-bearing
opportunities you

have to study product management
here at Stanford Online. But before we get
started, I do--

before we get started
going into the details, I wanted to give everyone a high
level overview of everything

that's available, all the
learning experiences that are available through Stanford
Online and the different kinds.

And then Liz and I will go into
more detail on some of these. So depending on your
level of experience,

depending on your
learning goals, and depending on your
level of commitment, we really have a lot
of different things

that you can consider. So we do have a fair
amount of free content. This informational session
is one example of it.

But Liz and I both run
and lots of our colleagues run webinars with
faculty and instructors on a variety of content but on
product management specifically.

And you can find
those on our website. You can also find those on the
Stanford Online YouTube channel.

We also have some
written content that you can find on
our Stanford Online. So some of these have been
written by the faculty

and instructors we work with. Some of these are prepared
based on our course content.

And so these are a really
wonderful opportunity if you're just trying
to explore the space. If you want to
familiarize yourself

with some of the instructors
that we have that teach our classes to get a
sense of their style, how they approach
this content, really,

a wonderful opportunity
and resource for you to go take a look at. And I'll also mention, we
have one program preview,

and that is just for the product
management professional program. And Liz will go into
more detail there. So that's an opportunity for
you to get a sense of what

the course experience is like. Again, the content is specific
to the product management professional program.

But again, that's free. And that's another wonderful
opportunity for you to get a sense of what our other
learning experiences are like.

The other thing I
will say is that some of the instructors for that
program, so specifically Anand and JZ, who you will
hear, probably, us

mentioned throughout, they also
teach the credit-bearing class. So it's also an
opportunity for you to get a sense of
what their dynamic is

and how they
approach the content. So in addition to
the free content, we have the
professional programs.

And again, there are
a variety of ways to learn this content, a
variety of levels of experience,

so advanced and more
entry level content. So depending on what you
want, there's a lot there.

Liz is going to go over all
of those different learning modalities and the
different levels of content. And finally, there is also a
course, a credit-bearing course,

that happens on campus that is
extended to online learners, that you also have an
opportunity to take.

Sometimes, we have it
several quarters a year. It's only being
offered this winter. Enrollment is open right now.

Enrollment will
close December 8. But if you're
interested in that, I'll be providing more
detail later in the session.

So with that, I'm going
to hand it over to Liz to talk about the
professional programs.

LIZ CAO: Sure,
thanks for that, Pax. So we'll start out focusing
on the professional education

program. So we have two programs
within this broader topic of product management.

So the first is our product
management program, which is targeted towards
people, who are either new to the field
of product management,

so people who are early
in their careers, people interested in becoming
PMs, or people in other roles like product
marketer, software engineers,

et cetera, who are
interested in learning more about the different
frameworks within PM.

And the second is our advanced
product management program. So this just launched this fall.

This program is
geared towards people, who already have working
experience as PMs and are looking to level
up in their careers.

So the courses in this
program would cover skills that you need to become,
like product leaders,

chief product officers, or
even like entrepreneurs, basically all the
career opportunities

available to mid-career PMs. So I'll talk about
this a little more shortly when I talk
about the PM program.

But we also have
different modalities of learning, so the self-paced
and instructor-paced modalities.

So self-paced means you can
sign up at your own convenience and complete the courses
at your own pace.

So you could complete a
course in a single day, or stretch it out over
the course of 60 days.

Upon completing that course, you
receive a record of completion. You can also pursue the
full program credential,

in which that case, the all
access plan would be a better option, since it gives you
access to all the courses.

And if you opt for
the all access plan, you can complete the courses
over the course of a year.

So currently, the advanced
product management is only offered through
these self-paced options.

But within the PM
program, we also have the accelerated program,
which is instructor-paced.

So it's the same lectures as the
ones in the self-paced courses packaged into a
10-week long program.

So you work with a group to
complete your assignments and ultimately
present a capstone.

And there's also
additional support offered through a team of
experienced PMs, who coach you

throughout the program. And I'll talk about that
a little more shortly. But first, PM program,
so diving deeper

into the self-paced program. So here, you'll see the
list of all the courses within the self-paced program.

So first, we have
the program preview. Pax had mentioned this. So the program preview
is really intended

to give you just a taste of
what the courses are like, and for you to see how the
interface of the platform

looks like, and get a sample of
the types of lectures offered. What types of exercise would
you typically do in a course?

So it's just a
sample to give you a taste of what the courses
are like before you go ahead

and make that purchase. And we also have the
remaining six courses.

So you'll see our two required
courses, the product management transforming opportunities
into great products,

mastering product management
building your strategy. So to earn the full credential
for the product management

program, you would need to
complete both of these courses. And then you would choose
two of these remaining four

elective courses. So we've built these
courses based off

of what we think early career
PMs need to know to succeed. But there's also a
lot of flexibility for you to pick and
choose which electives

are most appealing
to you and maybe more relevant for where you
are in your product management
journey.

And a little of a quick overview
of how the self-paced courses are structured.

So there are no prerequisites. So you do not need
to know anything about product management
to take these courses.

And there are no
particular technical skills you need to have to
take these courses.

They're really geared towards
early career product managers. So if you've already launched
product features or even

an entire product, the
content may be a little more

of a review for you.  The courses are composed of
recorded lectures of Stanford

faculty and instructors. And they also include written
exercises and multiple choice

final assessment. So each course, at the
end of each course, there's a final assessment
comprised of 20 multiple choice

questions. So to earn your credential
for that course, you would need to pass with
a score of at least 85%.

But you do have the option
to retake that final exam if you do not pass
the first time.

You also have support from
course facilitators via email. So within the course
interface, there's

an option to ask for help. So while you're doing exercise,
you have additional questions,

you can use that option to get
help and support from our course facilitators.

And lastly, even if you know
for sure this is the program, this is the course
for me, I'd still

encourage you to enroll
in the program preview, just so you can get-- again, it's just to confirm
whether these courses are

right for you before you have to
make any financial commitments.

OK, and now, a little preview
of what you see in the course. So like I said, the courses are
comprised of lectures and then

the different exercises. So this is what the lecture
interface looks like. You have the lectures on
the left with the captions.

And on the right,
you have the option to toggle between the slides,
the transcript, and any notes that you may want to take.

And all the lectures
are-- all the modules within the course are broken up
into different lecture segments

just to make the content
more digestible for you.

We also have the-- this is a sample of
one of the exercises you would do in the course.

So there's a mix of
multiple choice questions and written assignments
like this one that are more open ended.

And now, moving on to
the accelerated program.

So this program takes content
from those six product management courses I
had shown you earlier,

but are also on the edges of
the screen and distills them into a single
10-week long program.

So all the videos
and lectures you watched from in this program,
the accelerated program,

are sourced from
these six courses. And many of the assignments you
do in the accelerated program

are also adapted from
exercises in these six courses.

A quick overview
of the structure of the accelerated program. So like the self-paced
courses, there

are no formal prerequisites. But we do expect you to be
eager to engage with your peers.

Since this is a
time bound course and you are working
with other people, we do have a
stronger expectation

that you're willing to
engage with the materials and you'll be more
on top of deadlines. So it's less flexible than
the self-paced program.

Again, this program is geared
towards early career product managers. So really intended to take you
through the journey of creating

a product or a feature from like
a scratch from the beginning all the way to
actually launching it.

It's the same lectures as
the self-paced courses,

so just a different flow and
packaged in a way that makes sense for the 10-week
long sequence.

And then one key distinction
from the self-paced program is the support you get. So during the program, we
have weekly coaching sessions,

where the coaches, who
are all experienced PMs, walk through different
exercises with you, largely mirroring what you do in
the assignments with your group

and covering whatever was
covered-- touching, again,

on concepts covered in the
lecture videos and things you can expect in
your assignments. We also feature live sessions
with different guest speakers

to dive deeper into
different topics related to product management. With your assignments, you get
a lot of personalized feedback.

And lastly, you have a Slack
community with everybody else who's enrolled in this
program at the same time.

So you can communicate with
the coaches, your peers, people in your group, and
just anyone enrolled
in the program at that time.

So as I said earlier,
access to coaches is one of the key
differentiators from the cell-based program.

So the coaches are really
there to support you throughout the program. So they do this through the
weekly coaching sessions, Slack

and email support, and then
on demand office hours, depending on your group's needs.

We offer two coaching
sessions every week, so Wednesdays at 5:00 PM
and Thursdays at 9:00 AM.

This is just to try to
accommodate learners in different time zones
and their schedules.

Both sessions cover
the same content. They just may be led by
different coaches, who

may have a different way
of delivering the material. So if you're never--
if you're not available to attend
one session live,

you can always attend the other. And if you're not able to attend
either, they're always recorded.

And we share those
recordings over Slack. And we upload them into
the course page, too.

The other key differentiator
is the peer-to-peer interaction within the program.

So this mostly happens through
working with your group. So the capstone is a group
project that takes you

through the product life cycle. And you work with this
group starting in week one all the way through week 10.

So product managers
rarely work individually. So we strongly believe
a group project

like this better prepares
people for careers in product management. People are assigned into
groups based off of responses

in their pre-course survey. So in the survey,
you have the option to list out different
preferences.

Maybe you want to work with
people in similar industries or people in the same
geographic location.

And we do our best to try
and match people based off of these preferences. So caveat, we can't
guarantee that we
can accommodate all of them.

And just like a sample of a
typical week in the course, so this is week two.

So you'll see, we have the
assigned lecture content for that week is
all on user research

and rapid experimentation. The live sessions that week,
so the coaching session, focuses on user research.

And there's a live
session on need fighting for product managers
with Julie Stanford, who

teaches the user research
course on the self-paced course that week. And then that week,
your exercise assignment

is to actually make
a research plan. So that's just a typical
week in the course.

And this is also
a sample schedule of the different live events. So for the cohort that's
actually running right now,

like I said, the coaching
sessions are Wednesdays at 5:00 PM and Thursdays at 9:00 AM.

They have their capstone
presentations next week and then guest speaker sessions.

So we typically have four
different guest speaker sessions per cohort. For this cohort that's
currently going on right now,

we had one on AI for
product managers with Aditya Challapally, product strategy
with Donna Novitsky and Laura

Marino, a Q&A with JZ, and then
a session on usability research with Julie Stanford.

So these may change
from cohort to cohort. But that's just a sample
of the types of speakers

you can hear from and
what you can expect.

OK, before I move on to
the advanced program,

I'm just going to look
at the questions quickly. OK, so we have a few questions
about the program preview.

So if you go to week,
you'll receive a link after the webinar.

But you can enroll in the
program preview on Stanford on online.stanford.edu. And if you search for product
management program preview,

you'll need to create an account
on my Stanford connection. But the preview is
free and should be as

simple as clicking on a button. Similarly, to sign up for any
of the professional education PM

courses, you would need to just
click on the Sign Up button to register and enroll.

Yeah, so I will now move on to
advanced product management, OK.

So the advanced
product management, I think I mentioned
this earlier, this is a new
program that we just

launched earlier in the fall. So this program is
geared towards people, who already have PM
experience and are trying

to advance in their careers. So I would say,
there isn't a lot of overlap between the product
management program I was just

speaking about and the advanced
product management program. So these courses are
intended to cover

the skills you need to
progress as PMs to move on to your careers and to
become product leaders, head

of products. Currently, the course, the
program has four courses. So driving product strategy
through growth and change,

and getting buy-in
for your ideas. So when you compare these to
the ones in the PM program,

they start to get at bigger
picture, things like strategy for your entire company,
leading entire teams, innovation

and communication, which is an
essential product management skill that you can always
continue to improve.

Of these courses, so leading
product organizations

and beyond courses not live yet. So it will be available
starting March 2025.

Course structure, so
similarly to the PM courses, there are no formal
prerequisites. But again, this content is
really geared towards people,

like mid-career PMs. So may not be as relevant for
people earlier in their careers.

Like the other
self-paced courses, the courses are composed of
recorded lectures of Stanford

instructors and faculty. And they include
written exercises and the multiple choice
final assessment,

which, again, you would
need to score at least 85% to earn the credential.

And you can take the
exam multiple times. And if you have questions while
you're going through the course,

you can email the
course facilitators through the course page. I'm sorry, I clicked
too fast again.

And again, just

And again, you can
toggle between the slides and the transcript.

And here's a sample of one

be asked to do and think about.

And now, I'll hand
things off to Pax.

PAX HEHMEYER:
Great, thanks, Liz. And there was a question
about certification. And I'd encourage everyone.

So we have links at the

We have more information about

a whole page dedicated

to explaining the different
levels of certification and what the rigor is that's
associated with each one. What I'm going to talk about now
are the credit-bearing courses.

So these are
courses that you can take through Stanford Online
that are happening on campus

and that you would earn a
Stanford transcript for. So before I go into
details about--

before I go into detail
about the particular product management course that's
available This winter quarter for
enrollment, I do want

to take a step back and walk
through the larger opportunity.

Which is that each
year, we offer about 200 mostly engineering courses
through Stanford Online.

So these are, again courses
that are happening on campus, and that we extend to
online learners, who

take the courses alongside
the on-campus learners. And so there are 200
of these classes.

It's about 50 to 60 a
quarter fewer in the summer, more during the
regular academic year.

And they happen on
a quarterly cadence. So there's the fall courses,
the winter courses, the spring courses.

You are required
to meet the same-- do all the same work that on
campus students are doing.

It is the same course. You are enrolled alongside
the on campus students. I say that because it's both
an opportunity and a challenge.

It's an opportunity because it
is a really rare opportunity to take credit-bearing courses
at Stanford without having

to be admitted into a degree
program at the school. And I'll go over what
our approval process is

and how you apply for
the individual courses. It is also a
challenge, of course, because you are
taking a class that's

happening on campus as an
online learner alongside those on campus students. So you may be in New
York and you can't just

turn to the learner next
to you in the classroom and ask a question. So there are some of those
additional challenges.

And I'll go into a
little bit more detail about what the course experience
for the product management course is. But we recognize that.

But it is a pretty
amazing opportunity. You don't need to be
continuously enrolled

in courses. So any quarter that a course
you're interested in is offered, you can apply to
take that course.

Yeah, so you have opportunities. And you don't have to be
continuously enrolled. So again, if you take
a course this winter,

maybe you take this product
management course this winter, you really like it,
and then you think about, hey, maybe this summer,
I want to take a course,

too, I'm going to be too busy
in the spring to take a course, well, that's no problem. Then in the summer,
you find the course,

you roll and apply to
enroll in that course.

In order to keep
taking courses, you do need to meet a minimum
standard, which is B or better to keep taking classes.

And so basically, and I'll
go over the application again in more detail at the end
here, but you apply once, we keep that
application on file.

Then every time you request
to enroll in a course, we send your application
again to a department along with your
Stanford transcript.

They review it and you're
approved on a course by course basis. They're going to make sure,
do you meet the prerequisites for this course?

Have you been doing well
in the previous courses? But it's a pretty
unique opportunity. And again, product management
is a graduate level course

with fewer prerequisites. But we also have things like
advanced computer science, advanced electrical engineering,
chemical engineering classes.

So I'd encourage you to take
a look at the full catalog. Maybe you're a product
manager right now. Maybe you're a technical
product manager.

And so maybe you're interested
not just in product management but brushing up on some of
your engineering skills.

The other thing
I'll say about this is you can stack these courses
to earn graduate certificates.

So if you get approved and you
complete three or four courses and you do well
enough in them, you

can apply those towards one of
the 30 graduate certificates that we offer. And the product
management course

is part of three
graduate certificates. So if you did well
in the course and you were approved to take
additional courses

and you did well
on them, you could earn a graduate certificate. These are accredited
certificates. And again, you would have a
Stanford transcript to show

that you took these courses. So let me-- and sorry,
and the last thing

I'll add is if you were to be

18 of those units

towards a relevant

So what does this

management fundamentals for the real economy is a course
that happens winter quarter.

It's taught by Anand and JZ,

geared towards early career

product managers,
or someone who's interested in learning more

will be in the
course alongside you are advanced
undergraduates or early graduate students at Stanford.

And so it's taught
by Anand and JZ. They are industry professionals. They have many years of
experience as product managers

and a lot of companies
here in the Bay Area. And they run a weekly
lectures, three hour lecture.

It'll be happening on
Thursdays this winter quarter. And winter quarter
starts January 6. So it happens on Thursdays
at 4:30 in the evening.

You are able to join
those sessions over Zoom. So you can
participate real time. I say that because it's not

that we offer. But in this case,
you can participate in the weekly lectures live. They're also recorded if
you can't join them live.

And some participation
is required. The core of the program--
now, so those weekly lectures

include presentations, some
coursework, some panels, guest speakers. So there's a lot that happens
in those weekly lecture

sessions in addition
to Anand and JZ lecturing on the core content.

The core of the class itself
is this quarter long project.

And it is basically taking
you through one full iteration of the product lifestyle. So Anand and JZ
set that up, they

walk you through those
different milestones as part of that product lifestyle cycle. And then you're
submitting the project

along the way for review. You're revising it and you're
submitting a final product

lifecycle document at
the end for evaluation. The course itself
is 10 weeks long.

And most students report
spending 10 to 15 hours per week on the course. So it's a pretty
intensive program.

Again, 10 weeks, there's

the weekly sessions,

We ask for your

Then once your

Once you enroll in a

LIZ CAO: Sure. Yeah, so the first column, the

anyway, the all access

if you paid for
them individually. Next is the product management
accelerator program.

instructor-paced course, where you go through the course

early career PMs on the pace. So we have weekly assignments

There's a set start
date and an end date. So there's less
flexibility there. There's no application.
